title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for the identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by the Inspector General of an agency or other agency employee. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to require the Inspector General or designated agency employee to refer potential surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the agency's Chief Financial Officer for review and possible rescission if it does not hinder agency effectiveness. The agency must transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Treasury for deficit reduction, as per the "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013". Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 does not apply to these transfers. The agency must transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Treasury for deficit reduction. The head of an agency can retain up to 10% of the transferred amounts for cash awards to employees who identified the surplus funds. Annual reports on possible fraud, waste, or abuse must be submitted to the Director of the Office of Personnel Management. The head of each agency must submit an annual report to the Director of the Office of Personnel Management detailing disclosures of fraud, waste, or mismanagement by employees, total savings achieved, and cash awards given. This information must also be included in each budget request of the agency. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures that each agency includes information on fraud, waste, and mismanagement in their budget requests. They also oversee the cash award program of each agency and submit an annual report on Federal cost savings and awards to Congress and the Government Accountability Office. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management oversees agency cash award programs, ensuring compliance with regulations. They submit an annual certification to Congress and every 3 years, the Comptroller General reports on the program's operation and suggests any legislative changes.
